__data__.text: Picardo, born in Spain in 1919, lost his father at age 10 and moved to Madrid with his family. He initially aimed to join the navy, but the closure of military academies during the Second Spanish Republic led him to study law, which was interrupted by the Spanish Civil War. To stay in Madrid during the war, he joined architect Luis Moya Blanco's studio, who encouraged him to pursue architecture due to his talents. With many architects either dead, in exile, or disqualified after the Civil War, Picardo entered the Escuela Técnica Superior de Arquitectura de Madrid in 1945. His painting and drawing skills, especially his perspective mastery, were recognized by architects, leading to mural commissions and job offers for graphic representations and perspectives of their plans while still a student.

As a talented student, Picardo received mural commissions from architects and illustrated articles/covers for architectural magazines, showcasing sophistication and high-quality drawings. His work on murals and graphic representations became his primary source of income during his youth and early career. Picardo's post-student illustrations focused on Madrid in the 1950s-1960s, Spanish protectorate in Morocco, and Canary Islands. He developed a keen interest in historic architecture, preservation, and restoration, collaborating with architect and historian Fernando Chueca Goitia. After qualifying in 1951, Picardo joined Chueca in building preservation projects and became a signatory of the "Manifiesto de la Alhambra" in 1952, advocating for a Spanish modern architecture inspired by the Alhambra in Granada.

In the 1950s, Picardo, inspired by the Alhambra in Granada, joined other architects in advocating for a Spanish modern architecture style influenced by historic designs. He participated in competitions, publishing plans for uncommissioned buildings and co-designing an apartment building near Madrid's Plaza de Las Ventas. Picardo also built houses in Andalucían style on the Costa del Sol and in Jerez, and constructed modernist apartment blocks for Urbis in Madrid. His competition entries for Treasury Delegations in Gerona and Las Palmas, though not victorious, showcased his unique approach. Throughout his career, Picardo's work reflected his dedication to preserving historic architecture while incorporating modern elements.

In the 1950s, Picardo's exceptional drafting skills were recognized, leading to commissions for decorative mural paintings and illustrations in a popular architectural textbook. He also worked on the Ministerio de Información y Turismo's luxury hotel network. His mural paintings, known for vibrant colors and techniques, adorned various locations. Picardo's detailed architectural drawings were highly acclaimed by his peers. In 1959, he ventured into designing a unique baraja de naipes for the Spanish fashion brand Loewe. This summary highlights Picardo's versatility as an architect and artist, and his dedication to his work.

In the 1950s, Picardo's drafting skills gained recognition, leading to decorative mural paintings, illustrations, and unique commissions such as designing a baraja de naipes for Loewe. His imaginative baraja de naipes, featuring historical figures, received praise as "magnificent" from leading Spanish restoration architect Luis Menéndez-Pidal y Álvarez. Around 1960, Picardo also designed wooden chess pieces and published a book of his illustrations, Dibujos de José Luis Picardo. From the early 1960s to 1985, he dedicated much of his professional life to Paradores de Turismo de España, a state-run hotel chain, where he provided numerous illustrations and undertook various projects. These accomplishments demonstrate Picardo's versatility as an architect and artist and his dedication to his work.

In the 1960s, Picardo began a long-term collaboration with the Spanish Ministry of Information and Tourism, which operated the Paradores hotel chain. Given his background in historical restoration and interest in traditional architecture, he was tasked with restoring and converting old monumental buildings into luxury hotels. These projects, which included new constructions that mimicked the style of the original structures, aimed to preserve the historical appearance of the monuments while incorporating modern hotel amenities. Picardo completed eleven major reconstruction projects for Paradores over the course of two decades, with many Spanish and Portuguese architects following his lead. His work for Paradores is highly regarded for its historical imagery and romantic appeal.

Picardo's successful restoration of two historic buildings in Guadalupe for the first Parador project served as a model for other Spanish and Portuguese architects in the state-run hotel chains. The buildings, originally a hospital and a college, were in disrepair and had been altered over time. Picardo's mission was to preserve the original Mudéjar style of the structures while incorporating modern hotel amenities. He achieved this by using traditional construction techniques and materials, and carefully integrating new additions, such as a dining room and guest rooms, into the existing layout. The project is highly regarded for its historical authenticity and romantic appeal.

Picardo preserved the cloister's lower arches and enclosed the upper ones with glass and wooden latticework, while incorporating modern features like kitchens, service areas, and guest rooms in the historic buildings. He used traditional techniques and materials, and added a new wing of guest rooms in 1981. At the same time, Picardo was commissioned to design and build a Parador at the Castillo de Santa Catalina in Jaén, a 13th-century castle with a rich history. The restoration and design of these historic buildings established Picardo's reputation as a leading architect in the state-run hotel chains.

The Castillo de Santa Catalina in Jaén is a 13th-century castle with a history of damage from wars and abandonment. Picardo was commissioned to design a Parador there, choosing to build on the site of the old barracks and stables with a layout and design reminiscent of the castle. The first phase, opened in 1965, included a dining room, lounge, guest rooms, and service areas, with the structure concealed by traditional materials for an aged appearance. Picardo's design respected and paid homage to the neighboring castle.

The Parador at Jaén, designed by Picardo, features a 20th-century concrete, steel, block, and cement structure disguised with aging materials to match the neighboring castle. The first phase, opened in 1965, included drivers' rooms, a mechanical workshop, a dining room, a lounge, guest rooms, and service areas. In 1969, service rooms were added, converting the old service area into more guest rooms. Due to landslips, Picardo frequently reinforced the building in the late 1960s and early 1970s. A 1973 extension, connected by a tower, added 24 guest rooms, bringing the total to 43. The building, completed in 1978, was elevated to a Parador title. Picardo also designed interior medieval-style details and incorporated coats of arms from demolished buildings.

The Parador at Jaén was completed and given the title of Parador in 1978, following the addition of an extension designed by Picardo. He also designed the building's interior, incorporating medieval details and coats of arms from demolished buildings. Hand-painted ceramic tiles were used to decorate and credit those involved in the project. Picardo, who had previously worked on the Parador at Guadalupe, established a signature style of architecture and design that he continued to use in his future projects, including the Parador at Arcos de la Frontera in Cádiz, which he began working on in 1964. The Parador at Arcos de la Frontera is situated in the heart of the old town, on a triangular site overlooking the Rio Guadalete.

The Parador at Arcos de la Frontera in Cádiz, designed by Picardo, is situated in the old town and built on a triangular site overlooking the Rio Guadalete. Picardo decided to preserve some façades and demolish the rest, reusing seven columns in the new design. He encountered a problem with a crack in the cliff caused by an earthquake, which he addressed by constructing a patio as an independent structure. The building is designed in the style of an Andalucían residence, with an entrance hallway, a central patio, and small secondary patios. The dining and sitting rooms offer views of the river. Picardo incorporated Andalucían architectural features, such as exposed pine wood joists and terracotta floors, and designed much of the interior furniture and decoration.

In Arcos, Picardo designed and built a Parador with an initial 9 guest rooms, incorporating Andalucían architectural elements and reusing some structures from the old town. He later extended the building to 18 rooms, which opened in 1979. In Pedraza, Picardo restored the Casa de la Inquisición, transforming it into a hostería called "Pintor Zuloaga." He followed the local style, designing furniture and fittings, and opened it to the public in 1967. Picardo also considered expanding the Pedraza property by purchasing nearby buildings.

In both projects, Picardo designed interior furniture, lighting, and decoration, reusing features from previous projects and incorporating regional styles. He took advantage of existing structures and natural features, such as the cliff-edge view in Arcos and the medieval ambience in Pedraza. The Parador and hostería opened in phases, with the Arcos Parador completed in 1966 and extended in 1979, and the Pedraza hostería opening in 1967.

In the Pedraza project, Picardo had initially considered expanding the Hostería by purchasing nearby buildings to provide more guest rooms with extensive views of the Sierra de Guadarrama. However, these plans fell through due to difficulties in acquiring the neighboring property. The Hostería remained open until its closure in 1992 due to economic pressures on the Parador chain.

In Alcañiz, Picardo converted the Palacio de los Comendadores into a Parador, which was part of the Castillo de los Calatravos, a monastery-fortress built in 1179. The palace's south wing, which was flanked by two towers and divided into three floors, was assigned for the conversion. However, Picardo faced limitations in space, allowing for only 12 guest rooms. He designed the public areas by converting two large ground floor interiors on each side of the entrance, using the original guardhouse for the reception area and the old stables for the bar and cafetería. The exposed masonry of the walls and ceilings was preserved in these rooms.

In the Alcañiz project, Picardo converted the Palace of the Commanders into a Parador, with 12 guest rooms due to space limitations. The reception area was set up in the original guardhouse, and the old stables were transformed into a bar and cafetería. The main dining room, located on the first floor, was designed to resemble a palace's great hall, featuring a large fireplace and a coffered ceiling. Guest rooms were on the second floor, with raised areas for window viewing. The interior decoration was medieval-themed for the ground floor and palatial for the upper floors, with joinery, furniture, and ceramic murals designed by Picardo. In 1975, he planned a two-story wing to double the guest rooms, which was realized in 1998 by architect Carlos Fernández-Cuenca Gómez.

In 1975, Picardo designed a two-story addition for the neglected west side of the Alcúescar Commander's Palace to double the guest rooms, which was eventually constructed in 1998 by architect Carlos Fernández-Cuenca Gómez. The expansion, which incorporated many of Picardo's original ideas, increased the number of guest rooms to 38. The project in 1966 involved Picardo renovating a part of the palace, which previously housed stables and coach houses, into a Hostería. He preserved a sturdy building with four brick, groined vaults, transforming its lower ground floor into a bar and cafetería with a main entrance from the street. Picardo also built a one-story building at the rear of the plot, matching the architectural style of nearby structures, and utilized ashlar, solid brick, and pantiles for the walls and roofs.

In the 1966 project, Picardo transformed a part of the palace, which previously contained stables and coach houses, into a Hostería. He constructed a one-story building at the rear of the plot, consistent with nearby structures, using ashlar, solid brick, and pantiles for the walls and roofs. He also added a sgraffito image of the cross of the Orden de Santiago above the main entrance. Large areas were excavated for service areas, and a stone and iron enclosure with a gateway from the street to the patio garden was designed and built. The Hostería opened in 1971, featuring Picardo's pastiche medievalism, heavy timber, terracotta tiled floors, and medieval-inspired windows, doors, furniture, and light fittings.

Picardo later suggested converting the entire palace into a Parador, but this wasn't pursued until 1989, when the Hostería was closed due to low profitability. The rest of the palace was then restored and converted into a Parador with 27 guest rooms, incorporating Picardo's original Hostería. The entrance, bar, and cafetería area have since been transformed into a luxurious suite, losing the medieval atmosphere of Picardo's interior decoration and furnishings. Further expansions have turned the Parador into a larger establishment.

Picardo, who was commissioned to inspect potential sites for a new Parador, chose the southeast of the Alcázar del Rey Don Pedro in Carmona to build it. He decided to locate the building on the highest point of the town, overlooking the plains, and to position it such that it would overlap the foundations of the original castle walls, allowing for guest rooms within the sloping walls below the Parador's ground floor. However, this location and the damage caused by the earthquake of 1504 would create ongoing issues for the Parador. Subsequent expansions have turned the Parador into a larger establishment, and Picardo's original entrance, bar, and cafetería area have been transformed into a luxurious suite, losing the medieval atmosphere of his interior decoration and furnishings. Picardo was not involved in these later expansions and modifications.

The chosen location for the Parador by Picardo, which was built on the highest point of the town and overlooking the plains, was previously affected by an earthquake in 1504. This earthquake resulted in a deep crack and subsidence of the land, which was hidden by rubble and only discovered during the construction of the Parador in 1969. Despite the discovery of an underground fault, the ground was deemed stable for construction with protective measures.

Picardo's design for the Parador included a typical Hispanic-Arabic layout with two central patios, resembling the original fortress. The south and east walls of the building had four floors, while the entrance side had only two floors. The initial plan was for 23 double guest rooms and 10 singles, but a pre-completion expansion was decided by the Ministry, increasing the guest capacity from 56 to 102.

The earthquake and the location of the building led to permanent issues for the Parador, and subsequent expansions altered Picardo's original entrance, bar, and cafetería area, losing the medieval atmosphere of his interior decoration and furnishings. Picardo was not involved in these modifications.

The initial design for the Parador included two floors on the entrance side and 23 double rooms and 10 singles. However, a pre-completion expansion was decided by the Ministry, doubling the guest capacity to 102. The building was constructed with a concrete structure, clad with ashlar and brickwork, and featured a clay tiled roof with decorative chimneys. Picardo designed the interior with a Hispanic-Arabic style, using limestone columns, ceramic tiling, and brick. The rooms had marble and terracotta floors, and Picardo designed the furniture, lights, and other decorative elements. After the Parador's inauguration in 1976, a large crack was discovered along the south façade, and an expansion joint was constructed to divide the building into two zones. Picardo reported that the building had shifted 4 centimeters towards the valley. Subsequent expansions altered Picardo's original entrance, bar, and cafetería area, resulting in the loss of the medieval atmosphere of his interior decoration and furnishings. Picardo was not involved in these modifications.

After the Parador's inauguration in 1976, an expansion joint was constructed to address structural issues, dividing the building into two zones. The building had shifted 4 centimeters towards the valley, as reported by Picardo. The Service Geológico de Obras Públicas monitored the building and recommended underpinning the south wall's foundations. However, due to government policy, Picardo could not participate in the building's structural problem solutions after 1978. Despite underpinning in 1980 and 1987, and additional guest rooms and a new pavilion for conventions in 1987, further cracks were detected in 1996 and 2013. The building is currently at risk if the water table rises or another earthquake occurs. Improvements and modernizations were carried out in 1982-1983 and 1987 under different architects.

After the Ministry of Information and Tourism enlisted Picardo's help in 1964 to find a suitable old building to convert into a Parador in Guadalajara Province, he determined that the best option was the significantly ruined castle in Sigüenza. The castle, which had origins in Iberian, Roman, Visigothic, and Moorish times, had been repeatedly enlarged and modified until the 18th century, after which it fell into disrepair due to damage from various wars and the Spanish Civil War. By 1969, the castle was in a terrible state, with its military character compromised by alterations such as the conversion of towers into belfries and the addition of large windows and balconies. Picardo was tasked with analyzing the castle's condition and concluded that rebuilding the entire castle was necessary for the Parador to be constructed. The castle was converted into a Parador, and despite undergoing renovations and expansions, it continues to have structural issues and is at risk if the water table rises or another earthquake occurs.

In 1964, Picardo was asked to find a suitable building to convert into a Parador, and he chose the significantly ruined castle in Sigüenza. Due to its poor condition, he determined that the entire castle needed to be rebuilt for the Parador to be constructed. In his report to the ministry, he stated that the castle would be remodeled as completely medieval, without any remaining traces of later additions. The reconstruction began in 1972, during which most of the outer walls were raised, and the towers, including the twin towers of the fortified gateway, were further raised. Large windows, balconies, and other wide openings were removed to create a military external image. The plaster and rendering on the exterior walls were removed to reveal the original bare stone. Surrounding walls and towers were crenellated, and the central courtyard was cleared of post-medieval additions. Despite renovations and expansions, the castle continues to have structural issues and is at risk if the water table rises or another earthquake occurs.

In the castle's renovation, Picardo removed plaster and exterior additions to expose original stone walls and create a medieval appearance. He cleared the central courtyard of post-medieval elements and added window openings in the courtyard walls for light. The interior was rebuilt using modern materials covered by a historical facade. Key areas, such as the main reception, guest lounge, and dining room, were designed with specific features like timber-beamed ceilings, stone vaulting, and large fireplaces. Picardo also recreated the sgraffito decoration on the northern courtyard walls and installed facilities like a bar and café. Despite these improvements, structural issues persist due to potential water table rises or earthquakes.

In the castle's renovation, Picardo focused on creating a medieval atmosphere by exposing original stone walls, adding window openings, and using a historical facade to cover modern materials. The ground floor featured a dining room with large windows overlooking the Arroyo Vadillo and a vaulted bar and café on the courtyard side. Wide wooden staircases led to bedrooms, some with balconies and views of the town or courtyard. A lounge with a wooden ceiling and the original chapel were also preserved. A small monastic courtyard and banqueting hall with attached bar room were added, along with 80 guest rooms and a suite, accommodating 162 guests. Picardo designed interior decor with medieval-style furniture, flooring, and heraldic displays. A mural depicting the castle's history and restoration was placed in the entrance hall. Despite these improvements, structural issues remain due to potential water table rises or earthquakes.

In the castle's renovation, Picardo constructed a new mural in the entrance hall using 45 tiles, illustrating the history of the castle and the restoration process in his own words. He emphasized that while the building is mostly new, authentic parts such as the Romanesque chapel, entrance, towers, barbican, and Renaissance doorways were preserved and reconstructed. The perimeter of the castle was maintained, with the eastern façade being entirely new and the other three sides reconstructed and remodeled. The Parador was completed in 1976, opened to the public in July 1976, and was inaugurated by King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofía in April 1978. Picardo's last major project for the Paradores, the building underwent modernization in 1990 under Carlos Fernández-Cuenca Gómez, who adhered to Picardo's style, preserving the original character. Picardo also investigated and proposed plans for other old buildings to be converted into Paradores, but they were not completed during his working life.

In the 1960s and 1970s, Picardo was tasked by the Ministry of Information and Tourism to examine and suggest plans for various old buildings to be transformed into Paradores. He developed detailed proposals for several of these buildings, including the castles in Puebla de Alcocer and Monzón, and the old palace in Olite, Castillo de la Zuda at Tortosa, and castle at Cardona. However, only the last three were ultimately converted into Paradores, without Picardo's involvement in their completion. Other buildings Picardo surveyed, such as the Castillo de San Antón, Posada del Cordón, Palacio del Deán and Palacio del Dr Trujillo, and Castillo de Segunto, did not become Paradores. An access road was constructed for the Puebla de Alcocer project, but it was ultimately not realized. The Monzón castle conversion was deemed unfeasible by Picardo, and the idea was abandoned.

In the 1960s and 1970s, Picardo surveyed several buildings for potential conversion into Paradores, including castles in A Coruña, Atienza, Molina de Aragón, Valderrobres, Trujillo, Segunto, and Aracena, as well as the Posada del Cordón, Palacio del Deán, Palacio del Dr Trujillo, and the cave houses of Mesón Gitano. However, only a few of these projects came to fruition, and many were not undertaken with archaeological research, which is now considered controversial. In 1975, Picardo also developed improvements for the Parador at Ciudad Rodrigo.

In the 1960s and 1970s, Picardo focused on transforming historic buildings into Paradores based on his historical and architectural research, with many projects lacking archaeological investigation, which is now criticized. His conversion of Sigüenza castle-palace into a Parador has been particularly decried. Dr. María José Rodríguez Pérez has studied Picardo's work, describing the architects' goal as creating a convincing historical set design, often resulting in "false history" extensions. Picardo, however, defended his approach, arguing that if his reconstructions could be considered art, they were justified. He employed modern techniques while concealing them with traditional materials to maintain an antiquated appearance.

A Spanish academic praised Picardo's artistic approach, which involved using modern techniques disguised as traditional elements, such as a metal substructure supporting a rib vault or a concrete slab hidden beneath a coffered ceiling. Picardo believed that art allowed for such flexibility, and his architectural choices were based on his artistic sensibilities. Although historians now critique his work, Picardo's Paradores, such as those in Jaén, Carmona, and Sigüenza, remain popular. In addition to the Paradores, Picardo undertook various restoration projects, including the Catedral de Cádiz, Real Monasterio de Santa María de Guadalupe, Catedral de Santa María de Sigüenza, Ermita del Humilladero, Antiguo Palacio del Marqués de Montana, Palacio de Gamazo, Castillo de San Felipe, and Archivo Histórico Provincial de Salamanca. These projects demonstrate his expertise in classical styles and precise knowledge of restoration techniques.

Picardo undertook several significant architectural projects, including the rehabilitation of the Antiguo Palacio del Marqués de Montana, the rebuilding of the Palacio de Gamazo, the restoration of the Castillo de San Felipe, and the creation of the Archivo Histórico Provincial de Salamanca. His work was influenced by classical styles and modern techniques. In 1970, he was invited to design a new headquarters building for the Fundación Juan March in Madrid after Juan March was impressed by Picardo's work at the Parador in Jaén. Picardo's design, inspired by the classic perfection of the Parthenon and the constructive audacity of New York, won the competition in 1971. The building, started in 1972, was designed with continuous horizontal banding, ribbon windows, and white Carrara marble cladding, and most of it was buried below ground to maximize the garden area.

Picardo's design for the Fundación Juan March headquarters in Madrid aimed to maximize garden space by constructing most of the building underground, creating a cube structure with continuous horizontal banding and alternating ribbon windows of dark glass and white marble. The interior housed assembly halls, auditoria, exhibition spaces, libraries, offices, and car parking, with a focus on white marble, bronze, and walnut materials. Picardo integrated artworks into the architecture, including pieces by Eduardo Chillida, Pablo Serrano, and Joaquín Vaquero Turcios, and designed a large bronze double door for the south façade. The garden, also designed by Picardo, was a significant aspect of the project. The building was completed in 1975 to critical acclaim.

In the context of Picardo's work, the passage describes the design of the sala de equitación for the Real Escuela Andaluza del Arte Equestre in Jerez de la Frontera, completed in 1978. The building, commissioned by the Ministry of Information and Tourism, features a neo-Renaissance style inspired by Andalusian architecture, with an ochre exterior and white infilling inspired by traditional Andalusian village homes. The structure includes a large arena for horse displays, seating for 1,600 spectators, and stable facilities for 60 horses. The interior has a rectangular display area with six tiers of seating. The project was well-received, with one observer praising Picardo's control of proportions and ease in achieving a top-quality building.

In keeping with the neo-Renaissance design of the sala de equitación, Picardo incorporated classical elements such as relief pillars, arches, and a hip roof with dormer windows. The interior features a rectangular arena with seating for 1,600 spectators, and the color scheme of ochre and white is consistent both inside and out. The building also includes stable facilities for 60 horses, organized into five blocks radiating out from a central tack room.

Later, Picardo and García María de Paredes were commissioned to design a secure display for Picasso's Guernica in the Museo Nacional del Prado. The challenge was to protect the large painting with armored glass, which was only available in sheets smaller than the painting. To solve this problem, the painting was installed some distance away from the glass to avoid obstructing the view with the metal frame.

In order to display Picasso's large painting, Guernica, with armored glass, Picardo and García María de Paredes had to overcome the challenge of the available armored glass being smaller than the painting. They decided to install the painting at a distance from the glass to prevent the metal frame from obstructing the view. The painting was placed in a steel and armored glass case with bevels meeting the floor, walls, and ceiling for security. The main glass was set at a 10-degree angle to avoid reflections, and lighting was installed within the case. The room, originally a ballroom, allowed viewing of the entire canvas from 25 meters away. The painting was installed in September 1981 and opened to the public on Picasso's centenary. Reactions to the display were mixed, with some praising the location and method, while others, like British art critic David Sylvester, felt it was not displayed to its advantage.

The installation of Picasso's Guernica at the Museo Nacional del Prado faced criticism, as it was installed by the Círculo de Bellas Artes technicians instead of the Prado's staff, and British art critic David Sylvester argued that it was not displayed to its advantage. In 1992, the painting was moved to the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía, ending the use of the original Picardo/García de Paredes display. Picardo, elected to the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in 1997, gifted the academy his oil painting Guardia civil en el puerto de Alazores in 2000 and a portrait of himself by Luis García-Ochoa Ibáñez in 2023. Throughout his life, Picardo had a passion for architecture and horses, considering both to be perfections.

The academy houses a portrait of Picardo, painted by Luis García-Ochoa Ibáñez in 1953, which depicts him informally at age 34 and was donated by his sons in 2023. Picardo, an architecture enthusiast, received the Premio Antonio Camuñas de Arquitectura in 2001 for his contributions to architectural renovation. He married Trinidad de Ribera Talavera and had five children. Known for his energy, wit, and imagination, Picardo passed away in Madrid in 2010. The academy also displays a complex painting of twenty horses' legs in various colors and positions.
